conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the hemispheres A and B and use the conditions for equilibrium and friction.
Between the vertical walls are hemispheres A and B with masses m and 2m respectively, where the sphere of B is smooth and there is friction between the hemisphere A and the left wall.
The line between the two ball centers and the horizontal direction into A 30Â° Angle.
The maximum static friction is equal to the sliding friction force (g is the acceleration of gravity).
Identify the forces acting on each hemisphere.
The weight of hemisphere A is \( mg \).

premise: Normal force from the wall: \( N_A \)
conclusion: The normal force from the wall on hemisphere A is \( N_A \).

premise: Frictional force from the wall: \( f_A \)
conclusion: The frictional force from the wall on hemisphere A is \( f_A \).

premise: Normal force from hemisphere B: \( N_{AB} \)
conclusion: The normal force from hemisphere B on hemisphere A is \( N_{AB} \).

premise: Component of the normal force from B: \( N_{AB} \cos(30^\circ) \)
conclusion: The horizontal component of the normal force from B on hemisphere A is \( N_{AB} \cos(30^\circ) \).

premise: Component of the weight of B: \( (2mg) \sin(30^\circ) = mg \)
conclusion: The vertical component of the weight of hemisphere B is \( mg \).
The vertical component of the normal force from B is equal to the weight of A: \( N_{AB} \sin(30^\circ) = mg \).
The normal force from B is \( N_{AB} = 2mg \).
The horizontal component of the normal force from B is equal to the frictional force: \( N_{AB} \cos(30^\circ) = f_A \).
